Summary (warning: interpretation may be faulty)
- Moving atomic particles with electric charges have intrinsic magnetic fields;
- Atomic particles with magnetic fields all cancel each other out in an atom except when there's an imbalance of these particles at the edge of the atom;
- A bunch of these atoms---with unbalanced electric atomic particles at the edge of them---in a region of space align in a particular way such that their magnetic fields are aligned (ferromagnetic)

- When all of these defined regions of space (the domains) in a substance are ferromagnetic than that substance is MAGNETIC!

Your example is for soft Fe allowing all it's domains to be aligned, but there is also hardened Fe that won't allow domain shifting. The former example of "soft" would be wood nails. The latter example of "hardened" would be what is used in a electronic relay for the core which also has wire wrapped around it.
The core of a relay is non-magnetic but when a current is passed through the coil, that magnetic field is concentrated into the core with respect to the number of windings which turns it into a magnet. This us true ONLY when the current is flowing, if the current is removed [turned off] the core no longer has magnetic properties, those properties ONLY remain while the current is flowing. On the other hand, if a soft Fe core was used, when the current was turned off the core would remain with it's atoms aligned and therefore remain being a permanent magnet.

No. No, and no. GR allows that there is no "real" contraction other than in the inertial frame of the observer. Length contraction, time dilation are measurable and real perceptions of events in other, non-inertial frames. The classical relativistic theory breaks when considering parallel wires of (stupidĺy) infinite length because relative motion becomes immeasurable in practice i.e. observational frames of reference are indistinguishable in theory and in practice. Great. Now, how does GR get to work here? Because the charges must be non-inertial (that's the deltas as differentials in classical formulation, or the vector cross-products in the reformulated stuff) in any inertial reference frame. Wires must coil. Rail guns must pulse. Accretion disks must rotate. It's not that contractions or dilations or mass increases are "actual things" but because non-inertial behaviour accelerations can be observed or inferred. Thus goes the "twin paradox" out the window. This go simplistic descriptions of magnetism. Finally!!! The part I have been waiting for!!! NO ONE KNOWS WHY OBJECTS WITH ENERGY AND MOMENTUM ATTRACT GRAVITATIONALLY!!!! But we will say resolutely that magnetism and gravity cannot be related. I may be wrong that they are related, but those who attempt to say authoritatively that gravity is not a force, do so without real evidence.

If I drop iron, it hits the ground. If I drop helium, it hits the sky. Why is helium repulsed by mass until it gets to a specific level in the atmosphere? Like it is repulsed by a field. Repulsed with a force we can measure. I would argue that each element has a gravitational balance it is trying to achieve. Helium at a specific energy level freely bonds to other helium. But it doesn't freely bond with all other elements at the same energy level that it freely bonds with other helium. We use energy to change the attraction between elements so they bond with each other, but each element has a energy level where it best bonds with itself. I believe that is is caused by the force of gravity. Gravity seeks a neutral position where everything around it is gravitationally in balance with everything else around it. At different energy levels we overcome what the gravity of a specific element can bond with.

Because mass demonstrably bends time, we accept Einstein's theory that there is no gravitational force, making magnetism and gravity unrelated (if you choose to believe his conjecture). He didn't prove that there is no gravitational force. From a science perspective this is basically magic that we accept as science because we can see and demonstrate that it works. There is strong reason to believe that the relationship between time and mass exist as he theorized, but he never demonstrates how mass bends time. We accept, that because the larger principle has been shown to consistently predict things we can observe throughout the universe, his entire theory then must be true.

I only know of a few instances where we can do work without the consumption of energy. Gravity and magnetism are two of them, and the more I look for evidence that I am wrong, the more I am convinced that Magnetism and Energy are two presentations of the same force. Magnetism being a unique state of gravity, where the positive and negative polls of gravity are visible and can attract or repulse matter with opposite disposition. What if the normal presentation of gravity is to attract, but with small imbalances across groups of mass, you get both a negative and positive presentation of gravitational forces. Not enough to break physical bonds, but enough to generate fields of gravity / magnetism that we view through the interaction of other objects?

While MinutePhysics truly is remarkable and I did learn a lot from this, I’m pretty sure I’ll forgot this soon due to the YouTube Effect. So I hope I can do all of us a favour( including myself) by giving all of you a summary of this video. To make is relate as much as possible, I did it in the manner of question-answer:-
THE FUNDAMENTALS OF MAGNETISM:-
Required Knowledge:
1. What are magnets?
2. Behavior of magnets?
3. A basic(even if it may be limited) understanding of quantum mechanics.
Summary:-
Magnets behave as they do due to the fact that they extend magnetic fields out beyond the object.

Question 1: Where do magnetic fields come from?
Answer: Magnetic and electric fields are different aspects of the same thing( two sides of the same coin; especially as a result of an ingenious solution in special relativity[in Veritasium’s video]) i.e. they can be transformed into one another by way of motion causing electric fields to turn into magnetic fields for moving charged particles.
This explains many things we see in nature but something is still not quite good in our understanding.

Question 2: Iron and other metals are pieces of metal, what causes them to behave ‘magnetically’?
Answer: This is the first part of quantum mechanics helping us. Atoms have electrons moving in them. This is a particle with a property known as intrinsic magnetic moment which is a technical term for explaining that particles also behave as very “tiny magnets”. The reason behind why this happens is unclear(we don’t know it).
Atoms consist of protons with electrons revolving around them. So we have another question from this observation(a subpart to this the answer of this question).

Question 2.1: Are atoms also tiny magnets?
Answer: Yes. Atoms generate magnetic fields called orbital magnetic fields. But these don’t contribute due to the overall nature of magnetic fields in an atom. This is the second point where magnetic fields help us. Electrons are described in 4 sets of ‘objects’ in quantum mechanics-Principal shell, angular quantum number, magnetic quantum number and spin. We are interested in the last 2 for answering this question. We can use these 2 ‘objects’ to justify reasons for atoms
1. In filled shells, electrons move around in all directions causing current to cancel out thereby not generating any magnetic fields.
2. Electrons come in pairs(Pauli Exclusion Principle) with their intrinsic magnetic moment(remember ‘tiny magnet’) pointing in opposite directions( have opposite spins) thereby cancelling out each other.
But this is only the case for fully-filled shells(having electron pairs and opposing spins). In half-filled shells, electrons are unpaired. This intrinsic magnetism in the outer shells which gives atoms a majority of its magnetic field.

But chromium(having a half filled shell) isnt magnetic. This is another question!

Question 3: Why isn’t chromium magnetic?
Answer: This is due to the fact that there is a bigger scale to look at when considering this special case:Crystals. When atoms get together, they can either align their magnetic fields with each other or in the opposite direction. This is decided by whichever is the most stable.
This gives rise to the final piece of information to understand the nature of magnetic fields.

Question 4: Isn’t is possible for a group of atoms to have a set of atoms lining one way and another set another way?
Answer:Yes but one can apply magnetic field/force/pressure strong enough to create a sort of control over the other group of atoms causing sort-of magnetic behavior.

Conclusion(TL;DR): Magnetism is a fundamental( and beautiful) result of quantum mechanics.


This was a summary, I hope it helped you all out. If it did, I’m happy. But you can make me ever more happier by answering this question. Something I got out of natural curiosity.

For people how are interested: The mechanism of magnetism in crystal structures is pretty difficult to understand. In materials like Fe, Ni or Co, the mobile, spin polarized d-shell electrons are aligned parallel to each other by the Heisenberg interaction (a result of coloumb interaction and Pauli prinziple). Thus creating some energetically unfavourable state, which is compensated by the creation of domains which reduce their stray fields.
Unfortunately this is not the only type of magnetism in solids, the magnetism of Gadolilnium or YIG, for instance, is completely different from iron, Ni or cobalt, basically because these materials have no moving electrons, YIG in fact is an insulator, but still a magnet.

You forget to mention one thing:

If you can make particles small enough to encompass only a single domain, then the particle will be ferromagnetic.

If, on the other hand, you make the particle small enough, the particle will seem to be paramagnetic, because thermal agitation makes the directino of magnetism flip fast, averaging the magnetization to zero over a small time interval.

But again - if you're able to measure the instant magnetization fast enough, the particle will be measured as being magnetic. This is called superparamagnetism.

Cleared up a lot of basic questions I had about how magnets work. Ever since first exposure to them in elementary school, I only thought of them vaguely as something with north and south poles, with sort of a similar rule/behavior as electric charges. Even in highschool/AP physics, though we learned in more detail the various ways electricity and magnetism interact and were able apply Maxwell's equations, I developed sort of a slight dislike for E&M due to its less intuitive principles (compared to mechanics), and there was sort of a disconnect between eletromagnetism that showed up in my psets and "magnets" as I knew from elementary school. This video and its twin video on SR resolved most of these concerns (a lot of which are very basic, and I think should be better introduced in physics classes) satisfactorily for me.

What is the motivation of a kid that asks "How do magnets work?"?
I suppose it really wants to know if the magnetic effect can be explained by other forces which produce movement - it already knows "pushing"/mechanical force and gravity.

(In this case the answer could be: There is no invisible stuff that connects the magnets. We just call things that can pull each other without connections "magnets". Everything with weight pulls everything else a little bit - you only notice it with things that are as heavy as a planet: That is called "gravity". This is another of many differences between a magnetic field and a photon.

Also any magnet created is sort of making a chain on its own.  Take an iron C shaped core just like this letter "C" on the screen.  Wrap wire around it and send a short jolt of DC current through the wire.  The "C" shaped core developes pole ends with opposite polarity and one end of the C and the other end can be brought together and will stick together if the iron is flexible enough and your gap is small enough in your C shaped core.  It is this attraction to the opposite side of the C that keeps all magnetic alignment from rearranging in random order and cancelling.  Take and expand your C shape iron core and the other end is brought far enough away in proximity from the other end that there is nothing to keep its end aligned anymore and the magnetic alignments scatter and it will be significantly weaker.  All iron bar magnets operate this way, though, in a bar shape the ends are as far as they can get from the other that makes this shape the harder to make a magnetic alignment hold.

When you speak about crystals and talk about aligned magnetic forces vs. jumbled up forces.  I've experienced this with a Crushed ceramic magnet.  The powder takes on a new property like playdoh or water and is non magnetic as a whole(seemingly), however, place a strong magnet nearby and stir the cup of a crushed ceramic magnet they will all align again and it will become a large magnet once again.

You said "permanent magnets can only be fully understood as a quantum mechanical effect". It is not actually quantum mechanical, but relativistic effect. Does the Schrodinger equation contain spin? No, it doesn't! The Pauli equation contains it, but it was put there just to fit the equation for the experiment. It appears naturally only from Dirac's equation when taking limit speed of light equals to infinity! This effect is fully relativistic as well as the magnetic field itself. If you write some any law or equation in CGS units you'll see that all the magnetic things just disappear if speed of light equals to infinity. Formula for this Bohr magneton contains c in denominator in CGS units. The whole effect just disappears if you don't consider theory of relativity! Quantum mechanics can not explain permanent magnets on its own, you need relativistic quantum mechanics(not just quantum mechanics), especially Dirac's equation.

Just as we think of "Space" as Height, Width and Depth, "Time" is just another dimension. Try and think of it as drawing a cube on a piece of paper. You draw the width and the height, making a square. You draw the depth to make the cube, but the PAPER has to exist for the cube to exist, right? The paper is time.

Just an easy to understand metaphor. It's a lot more complex than that, but that's one of the general accepted theories.

Time passing is our way of looking at the 4th dimension just in little chunks at a time because we can't see the actual 4th dimension.

Think of it like this, if you could only see in 2 dimensions and you had a box you could only see one side at a time (no perspective) so you would have to turn the box to see all the sides.

For the same reason the earth doesn't 'run out' of gravity -- the attractive force of magnetism is not energy in itself. It can be used - so for example it can attract a nail, but then to remove the nail from the magnet takes as much (or more) energy than was produced by the initial attraction.

This is why attempts at creating a perpetual motion machine using magnets doesn't work.

Well its more like quantum particles trying to maintain the conservation of angular momentum. The intrinsic magnetic moment or the "spin" of a particle causes the angular momentum to favor one direction, so that particle is "attracted" to another particle of the opposite angular momentum. So technically, opposites do attract.
lmao!

Not exactly. Classical magnetic force wants to anti-align neighboring magnetic dipoles.

In a ferromagnet, short-ranged electron spin alignment is a competition between this drive to anti-align with its neighbor and a quantum effect, called "exchange", which is basically a fancy manifestation of the Pauli exclusion principle that wants to align spin. In short-distance, exchange wins, hence domain of neighboring electron with aligned spin.

The simple fact that magnets are magnetic. The material itself is magnetic.  If the magnetic attraction to the material is stronger than the repulsive force, then they attract.  And this is a very easy thing to set up and play with.  Simply get two disc magnets that have different size radius.  You can put north pole to north pole (or vice versa) and have the small magnet stick to the larger magnet.  Try it.  The bigger the difference in radius, the more they attract.
